channel.title: World Time? (not sure how to say it)
channel.description:
So I'm trying to make a method that runs every second.
I tried doing the while (true) thing but I know that that is a horrible way to do it, also the interface doesn't even load haha. Any ideas on making a very simple one?

item.title: World Time? (not sure how to say it)
item.dc:creator: @Docent Limits
item.description:
@Docent wrote:

[quote=“zyle1992, post:9, topic:544471”][quote author=Limits link=topic=663351.msg4433173#msg4433173 date=1404166669]

You could do something like this:


        ScheduledExecutorService threadPool = Executors.newScheduledThreadPool(8);
        final Callable<Boolean> task = new Callable<Boolean>() {
            @Override
            public Boolean call() {
                return true;
            }
        };
        threadPool.schedule(task, 600, TimeUnit.MILLISECONDS);

I’ll try it out after I finish combat. Thanks man!
[/quote]

I posted the wrong code. to schedule it at a fixed rate, do this:

[code=Java]

    ScheduledExecutorService threadPool = Executors.newScheduledThreadPool(8);
    final Runnable task = new Runnable() {
        @Override
        public void run() {
            System.out.println("Tick");
        }
    };
    threadPool.scheduleAtFixedRate(task, 0, 600, TimeUnit.MILLISECONDS);
    [/code][/quote]

Alright, noted thanks!

Read full topic
item.source: World Time? (not sure how to say it)

        ScheduledExecutorService threadPool = Executors.newScheduledThreadPool(8);

[/quote]

I’ll try it out after I finish combat. Thanks man![/quote]

I posted the wrong code. to schedule it at a fixed rate, do this:

[code=Java]

    ScheduledExecutorService threadPool = Executors.newScheduledThreadPool(8);
    final Runnable task = new Runnable() {
        @Override
        public void run() {
            System.out.println("Tick");
        }
    };
    threadPool.scheduleAtFixedRate(task, 0, 600, TimeUnit.MILLISECONDS);
    [/code]
